What a dream it is to be in ARGENTINA!🇦🇷🍷⠀
⠀
Thank you to all who have followed my stories so far. Much much more content on the way! As an update, today was my first official day in wine country. We’re in Cafayate which is in the Salta Provence in the northern part of the country. The altitude in this area reaches about 6,000 feet!🏔️ It’s HOT during the day, but these diurnal temperature shifts are crazy. It drops about 30 degrees Fahrenheit! ⠀
⠀
Thank you @winesofarg for this incredible experience. Stay tuned for all the content!⠀

What an incredible day in Cafayate visiting @bodegamalaya (along with tasting @bodegacolome), and Bodega Piatelli!🇦🇷🍷⠀
⠀
As I mentioned, the Salta Province sees some of the highest elevations in Argentina. The vineyards are found at the foothills of the Andes.🏔️ Because the grapes are so close to the sun, the UV rays are incredibly strong. This causes the grape skins to become thick as they try their best to protect themselves. You often find these “mountain wines” to be dark, tannic, and very opulent. Due to the extreme temperature shifts between day and night, the acidity in the berry is retained. ⠀
⠀
What a great visit at Bodega Amalaya who are part of the same family as the famed, @bodegacolome. The wines of Amalaya are blends and come from different terroirs, while the wines of Colomé come from extreme high elevations and are single varietal. The story of this producer made every single one of us cry…audibly without shame. It’s too much to type so it will have to go in my stories!!⠀
⠀
Big thanks to the Piatelli family for a great tasting and dinner! More on that property later! Top wines of the day:⠀
⠀
Amalaya Grand Corte Malbec, Calchaquí Valley 2021⠀
⠀
Colomé “El Arenal” Malbec 2020⠀
⠀
Colomé “Altura Maxima” Malbec 2021⠀
⠀
Thibault Delmotte Malbec Natural 2020⠀
⠀
Piatelli Vineyards Limited Edition Cabernet Franc 2019, Valle de Cafayate, Salta⠀

SAVE THIS POST for a luxurious spa resort in the heart Mendoza wine country🍷🧖🏻‍♀️⠀
⠀
Susana Balbo isn’t just making delicious wines, she’s also launched one of the most luxurious spa resorts in Luján de Cuyo. When we arrived to the winemaker’s house, we were greeted with fresh-squeezed orange juice and cold towels followed by a lunch with the best fillet mignon I’ve ever had!🥩⠀
⠀
All of her top wines are on the restaurant lists and stocked in the wine fridges in each of the spa suites. The skin-contact Torrentes was *chef’s kiss.*😚🤌🏼⠀
⠀
We each experienced a 3-hour ritual which included a full-body exfoliant, body mask, and massage right in our suites. HEAVEN!⠀
⠀
Dinner outside was incredible too. I can’t recommend this place enough! What a treat!! Check out their page for more info.🇦🇷 @susanabalbohotels

It’s been so amazing sharing all about the Chianti DOCG with you this past year! I wanted to “sweeten the deal” a little by talking about Vin Santo del Chianti!🍷A D⠀
⠀
It’s the holiday season which means we’ll be indulging in a lot of sweet treats.🍫🥧🍮Vin Santo del Chianti is the perfect partner as grapes for this wine are laid out to dry which concentrates the sugars. The wine is then matured oxidatively in chestnut oak lending notes of toffee, caramel, almond, and butterscotch😋 Try it with apple pie, vanilla ice cream, Christmas cookies, or do as the Italians do and pair it was some biscotti!⠀
⠀
Interested in learning more about this incredible wine region? Make sure to follow @consorzio_vino_chianti! #ChiantiLovers #ChiantiWine #Chianti⠀
⠀

CELEBRATING MY BIRTHDAY WITH @champagnetaittinger 🍾🥂🥳 A D⠀
⠀
It’s been an incredible year of good friends, travel, and of course, GREAT wine. Every year on my birthday, I choose a memorable champagne to share, and this year it’s @champagnetaittinger Brut Millésimé 2015🔥⠀
⠀
Besides being one of the few remaining family-owned and operated Champagne houses, Champagne Taittinger is unique because they always use a high portion of Chardonnay in their cuvées and put the wines through extensive aging, even more than the legal requirement. ⠀
⠀
This 2015 is PERFECT for any celebration. It’s round yet crisp with a creamy mousse and very fine bubbles.🥂 ⠀
⠀
Cheers to every single one of you! Thank you for being with me on this incredible journey! @kobrandwines #champagnetaittinger #theinstantwhen⠀

Although you never need a reason to open a good bottle of Chianti Classico, the holiday season has me reaching for @cecchi_winery🍷🎄 A D
⠀
@cecchi_winery has been making wine for 130 years! Today, innovation and tradition are at the helm of all the family does. ⠀
⠀
Storia di Famiglia Chianti Classico DOCG is the perfect sip to celebrate the season. It’s intense ruby with ripe tart cherries, crushed cranberry, dried rose, clove, and dried herbs. The palate is round with fine-grained tannins and abundant freshness😋 It’s the kind of wine that would please a large audience making it a great addition to your holiday table. ⠀
⠀
How would you pair this wine?!👇🏼 #cecchiwinery

I learned SO much in Argentina and there’s still much to share🇦🇷🍷⠀
⠀
With the extreme altitudes, sunscreen and either an umbrella or hat are a MUST due to the proximity to the sun and therefore strength of the UV rays! Did you know the conditions here are desert-like? Without irrigation it would be almost impossible for viticulture to be viable.☀️🌵⠀
⠀
Producers here mostly use drip irrigation which is when a series of small pipes are connected to a trellis along the vine rows and water is administered in a controlled way. The second form of irrigation is flood irrigation where troughs are dug between rows and melt water from the Andes is used to “flood” the vineyard. Water can be scarce and the producers work together to share their natural resources.🏔️⠀
⠀
Malbec is the ⭐️ here and it shows very ripe and opulent. We’ll chat more about Malbec specificities another time.🍷 Did you learn something new?! Ciao for now!
📍 @salenteinbodega

A successful adventure to Porto!🇵🇹⠀
⠀
Quite possibly Europe’s best kept secret (which is definitely becoming not so secret anymore). Porto is the land of Port wine which is a fortified wine made from a blend of indigenous varieties found in the Douro Valley. Historically, the wine would be made in the Douro and then shipped over to Vila Nova de Gaia on Rabelo boats to mature in cooler, more “Atlantic” conditions. Today, unfortified still wines are taking the spotlight and gaining more momentum (exciting!), but Port wine will always be a staple of the region.🍷⠀
⠀
My big fortified wine exam is coming up and Port was always a struggle for me. Why not take a quick trip to immerse myself? A huge thanks to my Porto tribe (especially @rafaeldelima91) for your hospitality and forcing me to write out full WSET tasting notes for every wine I tasted.🙃 It was also great to see my friends at @jdselections …great things to come! I ❤️ Porto.⠀

What a great day tasting with Gurrieri at @damichelenyc 🍷🍕⠀
⠀
You can find Gurrieri the countryside of the Iblei Mountains, in the fertile Val di Noto, which is in the area of Cerasuolo di Vittoria (the only Sicilian DOCG).🇮🇹 This small, organic production of Frappato and Nero D’Avola (and Grillo) is extremely unique as in 2013, Giovanni Gurrieri created the first white wine from black grapes in Sicily.😮 The wine called, Donna Grazia is a blend of Frappato and Nero D’Avola that is immediately pressed off the skins to create a white wine. It’s bright, mineral, floral & packed with pink citrus fruits😍⠀
⠀
My other favorite? No surprise, it was the Cerosuolo di Vittoria which is the same blend as the Donna Grazia but red! The wine was bright, fresh and juicy with great structure and fruit concentration. It’s lighter in body and an absolute DELIGHT to the palate.😋⠀

Nice to meet you🥰⠀
⠀
Most of you have been around for awhile, but if you’re new here here is a quick reintroduction. ⠀
⠀
I’ve been sharing wine recommendations on Instagram since early 2017. Some would say I’m one of the “OG” wine creators.🤳 I fell In love with wine after a trip to Napa in 2014 and knew I needed to be a part of the industry. I was just coming out of a professional dance career and could link so much of wine to dance (the storytelling, the artistry etc.) It felt like home.🏡⠀
⠀
I started making my way through the @wsetglobal program to make sure I wasn’t spewing BS (there’s a lot of that on IG!), and today I’m currently a WSET Diploma candidate (D1, D2, & D5 completed). I also received my French Wine Scholar right before being hired by a Burgundy Château where I’m a private client advisor by day. ⠀
⠀
I love giving wine & wine region recommendations and introducing the consumer to something they’ve never tried before. I also love traveling and base my itineraries around wine regions and wine-focused gastronomy.🍷⠀
⠀
If you’re looking for a buddy in wine for either help/recs or to geek out with, I’m your gal and hope you’ll follow along!🥰⠀

SAVE WATER DRINK CHAMPAGNE!🍾⠀
⠀
Hello from the US Virgin Islands!🌴 We came here for a quick beach getaway and of course we packed all of our own wine🍷(it’s hard to get wine down here and often restaurants have to work with massive distributors that have the resources and bandwidth to supply the Caribbean). @seasaltvi is new here on St. Thomas and has one of the better wine lists around.🌊 ⠀
⠀
With that being said, let’s talk about this @champagne_henriet_bazin “Hypolite” Premier Cru we brought. This is 100% Chardonnay coming from the Premier Cru village of Villers-Marmery. The base wine is aged in oak barrels that are made from the forest of Villers-Marmery, keeping true to its unique terroir🌳 This wine is extremely textured and provides a layered toastiness that could only be associated with oak. It paired perfectly with our Chilean sea bass and snapper 😋⠀
⠀
Do you bring your own wine on vacation?👇🏼⠀
•⠀
•⠀
•⠀

The ocean and Chablis🌊🍷🐚⠀
⠀
Getting back to the ocean has been amazing and this ocean & Chablis pairing is a match made in heaven. Introducing @maisonjosephdrouhin Drouhin - Vaudon Premier Cru “Mont de Milieu” 2017. Mont de Milieu enjoys higher temperatures and more hours of sunshine than other plots thanks to its location southeast exposure. Because of this, you’ll find riper fruits and a certain richness that is beautifully balanced out by minerality🐚🪨⠀
⠀
Soils here are Kimmeridgian which is a mix of limestone and clay made millions of years ago (approx 150) when ancient sea creatures and organic matter died and settled to the bottom of the sea. They would then fossilize to become part of the soil rich in calcium carbonate. Even today you can still see the fossils in the rocks!⠀
⠀
Now you can see why Chablis and the ocean is such a perfect pairing 😉 ⠀
⠀
On the nose: Meyer lemon, white blossom, crushed oyster shell, lime zest, and salty sea air. Notes carry through to the palate where the wine shows a med (+) body, high acidity, and a nice round finish. 🍋🪷🐚🌊⠀

With the prices of Burgundy from the Côte d’Or skyrocketing, where else can we look? The answer may lie in the Côte Chalonnaise!🇫🇷⠀
⠀
The Côte Chalonnaise is located just north of the Mâconnais and south of the Côte de Beaune. It possesses a continental climate with Chardonnay & Pinot Noir being the star grape varieties.🍷⠀
⠀
I headed to Rully to discover this beautiful Chardonnay from @domaineroismages. “Les Cailloux” translates to “the pebbles” as its named after the stony soils it grows on. The plot is only 3 hectares with only 1.3 hactares planted to Chardonnay! The grapes are gently pressed and the must is clarified naturally by settling. The fermentation happens in barrel (10% new) with indigenous yeasts. Lees stirring (battonage) happens everyday during alcoholic and malolactic fermentations. The wine then sits in barrel for one year without any stirring or racking. Take it from me…the wine is delicious.🙌🏼 It’s soft and round with abundant minerality and bright acidity. The fruit, wood, and malo are all perfectly in balance. What a treat with my Caribbean lobster!🦞⠀
⠀
Have you explored the Côte Chalonnaise yet?⠀

The soils of the Mâconnais are a testament to the region's fascinating geological history!🍷🇫🇷⠀
⠀
Millions of years ago, the area was covered by a warm, shallow sea, which left behind deposits of limestone and marl. Over time, tectonic activity caused the sea bed to rise and fold, creating the complex topography that we see today.🌊⠀
⠀
The resulting soils are incredibly diverse, ranging from rocky limestone to rich clay, and they provide the perfect foundation for the region's world-famous wines. Each plot of land in the Mâconnais has its own unique combination of soil types, which give the wines from that plot their distinctive flavor profiles.⠀
⠀
If you're a wine lover or a geology buff, a trip to the Mâconnais is a must. Explore the fascinating terroir of this incredible wine region, and discover the many stories that its soils have to tell. ⠀

Let’s talk about Hello Grappa!

Grappa is a spirit distilled from grape skins after they’ve gone through wine fermentation. Grappa is unique to Italy and is even protected under a G.I. (Geographical Indication). 🇮🇹

The grape skins come from famous Italian wines like Moscato, Barolo, and Brunello. You can even pick up nuances from those grapes in Grappa! Grappa is great on its own, but also delicious in a cocktail. Here’s a simple cocktail you can enjoy at home:

Grappa Tonic

2/10 Grappa
2/10 Orange Juice
6/10 Tonic Water
Garnish with orange slice and thyme 

Cheers! @hellograppa #hellograppa #europeanessence #authenticspirit #enjoyitsfromeurope [A D]

Sustainable farming is not just a buzzword in the Mâcon region, it's a way of life for winemakers like Romain from @domainecornin 

With a deep respect for the land and a commitment to preserving it for future generations, they have embraced organic and biodynamic farming practices that promote soil health, biodiversity, and sustainability. From using cover crops to control erosion and attract beneficial insects, to composting and reducing water usage, their holistic approach to winemaking is a testament to their dedication to the environment. This isn’t just a trend for them, they’ve been farming this way since 1993🤯

But it's not just about being environmentally responsible. These practices also result in wines that are pure expressions of the terroir, with a depth of flavor and complexity that can only come from healthy, well-tended vines.🍷🌱

An incredible visit at @pierre_paillard!

Pierre Paillard is a family-owned winery located in the picturesque Grand Cru village of Bouzy in the Montagne de Reims. Quentin & Antoine are the 8th generation growers carrying on the legacy that goes back 200 years!🍾

The brothers have a real sustainable and “hands-off” approach to wine growing and winemaking. They use organic compost to build up the humus in the soils (this helps with soil structure and biodiversity), and natural sprays made of tea to make sure they aren’t harming the natural micro-organisms and beneficial insects in the vineyard.🌱🐛

When it comes to winemaking, vinification happens by plot to express the unique terroir, and malolactic fermentation is never stopped. Extensive lees aging is common with some cuvées resting in the cellar up to 10 years!🥂

What is my opinion? These champagnes are STUNNING! They are precise, energetic, textured, and complex. They give and give and will continue to do so over many years in cellar. All cuvées are imported to the US, so I encourage you to grab a bottle (or 6) and thank me later😜

Thank you so much to Antoine for taking the time to taste with us, and @cathrynboudiak for the brilliant visit!

In my Finger Lakes viticulture era🍇

The Finger Lakes region is characterized by its unique soils and climate, which are perfectly suited for growing several grape varieties…especially RIESLING! The region's soils are a mix of shale, limestone, and sandstone, which give the wines a unique mineral characteristic. The lakes are extremely deep and hold heat in the winter and cool things down in the summer producing grapes that fully ripen and retain high acidity.🍷 

The history of winemaking in the Finger Lakes region goes back over 150 years, with the first commercial winery opening in 1860. Since then, the region has become known for producing some of the finest Rieslings in the world, as well as other varietals like Chardonnay, Cabernet Franc, Blaufränkisch, and Saperavi.🍇

It’s International Sauvignon Blanc Day!🎉

Sauvignon Blanc is a late budding, early ripening white grape variety grown all over the world. Initially from France, Sauvignon Blanc is tied to the word “Sauvage” translating to “wild” due to its vigorous nature.🍇

It has since found a wonderful home in Marlborough, NZ thanks to its abundant sunshine, cool nights, and free-draining soils. Sauvignon Blanc expresses notes of citrus, tropical notes, and distinctive jalapeño or bell pepper aromas due to unique compounds called pyrazines found naturally within the grape. 

This #sauvblancday we’re celebrating with @villamariawines who really captures the essence of Marlborough. Grab a friend or loved one and transport yourself to New Zealand’s coast!🌊 #VillaMariaWines {A D}

An elegant and enchanting evening in NYC with @vik_wine ❤️🗽

We were amongst the first in the US to taste the latest “Artist Collection” release which so happens to be a champagne called, “La Piu Belle.” This champagne is a 2009 vintage with grapes coming from Aÿ. It’s incredibly elegant with a fine, persistent mousse and layers upon layers of texture & flavor intensity.😍🍾 The bottle design itself is also a masterpiece created by artist, Elena Triana. 

Then onto the main event - a vertical tasting of VIK in 2010, 2015, 2017, & 2019 led by charismatic winemaker, @cristian.vallejo.winemaker. It was truly a moment of joy mixed with study as we danced from glass to glass chatting about the nuances of each vintage. It was amazing to see and taste the story and evolution of each wine, something Cristián refers to as “the personality” each wine possesses.🍷

I also loved learning about their new “Barroir”(barrel/terroir) program that started with the 2019 vintage where they use Chilean oak to toast the inside of their barrels. A whole new meaning of “place!” Thank you so much to the VIK team for having us.🙏🏼

Riesling is a white grape variety that is known for its aromatic nature and its ability to produce a wide range of wine styles, from bone-dry to lusciously sweet.😋

One of the reasons Riesling is so versatile is due to its high acidity. This acidity helps to balance out the sweetness in sweet wines, while also providing structure and freshness to drier wines. Additionally, the grape has a unique flavor profile that often includes notes of citrus, peach, apricot, petrol, wet stone, and honey.🍋🍑🍐🍯

It’s Important to note that some of the world’s most famous Rieslings are bone-dry, crisp, and refreshing (like these Finger Lakes wines). So, if you’re a fan of white wine but haven’t explored the world of Riesling yet, there’s plenty to discover🙌🏼

What a special night with @champagnelaurentperrier, @wineenthusiast, & @meetresident! 

I’ve fallen in love with these cuvées all over again and it’s easy to see why. Freshness & elegance are a given, but we can also add finesse, precision, and depth!🍾😍

The most unexpected pairing for me was the Ultra Brut with the Insalata Verde. Ultra Brut was coined by the House and then produced in 1981 as “zero dosage” aka no sugar added. I initially thought this could feel harsh on the palate with the asparagus and fava, but the addition of whipped ricotta allowed everything to work together in beautiful harmony. In fact, the freshness of the cuvée worked perfectly in parallel with the freshness of the vegetables.🥂

The Grand Siècle is always a treat - it’s the House’s Prestige Cuvée and it’s unique because it’s non-vintage. The House believes the sum is greater than its parts and takes the best from a few vintages to create this cuvée in perfect balance and with great complexity!

Special shout out to Chef Owen L’Aquila for his impeccable execution, and @annachristina722 & @poisedpoyser for your beautiful explanations & guidance! Cheers!🍾🥂

It’s National Chardonnay Day!✨✨ Although this is one of my favorite white grape varieties, I understand that it can be very misunderstood.

Chardonnay is kind of a chameleon. It’s fruit expression depends on where it’s grown (more apple & citrus in cool climates and more stone fruit and tropical in warm climates), but it’s also easily manipulated by a winemaker. Practices like oak aging, malolactic fermentation, and lees aging all greatly affect how a Chardonnay tastes. 

In the 80s & 90s, big oaky buttery wines were all the craze. There were also huge companies pumping out mass produced Chardonnay and using things like oak chips & staves to meet demand. That kind of thing still goes on today, but that doesn’t mean that’s representative of the grape by any means!

If you love refreshing whites with a lighter body & high acidity, check out these 3 regions for some beautiful Chardonnay:

Chablis, France 
Champagne (Blanc de Blancs) 
Willamette, Oregon
Bonus: Trentino-Alto Adige

It’s true!

When we drink white wine at too low of a temperature, we lose a lot of the beautiful aromatic qualities of the grape. White wine that’s too cold can also feel austere and sharp of the palate. If I’m served a glass of white wine with crazy condensation going on, I usually just wait a few minutes for the wine to come up in temperature and show its full expression🥂

When we drink reds too warm, the wine can feel more bitter and alcoholic. I always chill my reds down a bit either quickly in the fridge, or in an ice bucket. Want to know the best drinking temps? Check below!👇🏼

🥂Sparkling wines 43-50F (6-10C)
🍷Sweet wines 43-45F (6-8C)
🍷Light-Med bodied whites 45-50F (7-10C)
🍷Med-Full bodied/oaked whites 50-55F (10-13C
🍷Light bodied reds 55F (13C)
🍷Med-Full bodied reds 59-64F (15-18C)

Getting to know Prosecco isn’t as black and white as it may seem!🍾

When you see DOCG on a Prosecco bottle it means the grapes were grown on what’s considered “ideal” vineyard sites, usually on slopes for great drainage facing east or southeast. DOCG Prosecco is also made from smaller yields meaning there will be more flavor concentration in the final wine.🍇 Sometimes you won’t even see the word “Prosecco” on these bottles. They may just say “Valdobbiadene” or “Cartizze” signaling that the grapes came from very specific areas or vineyard plots. These wines are great for sipping at brunch or apero. 

When you see DOC on the label, it means the grapes were still grown within the limits of what can be considered Prosecco; however, the sites are usually the flatter, more fertile plains. Yields for these wines are larger than DOCG (125 hl/ha)! These wines are perfect for that aperol spritz, mimosa, and spagliato!🥂

🍇 Franciacorta: A Blend of Terroir and Tradition 🥂🇮🇹

🗺️ Geography and Location:
Franciacorta is a picturesque wine region situated in the Lombardy region of northern Italy. It is positioned between the southern shores of Lake Iseo and the city of Brescia. The region’s unique geographic location plays a crucial role in shaping the character of its wines.

🌿 Terroir and Soil:
The terroir of Franciacorta is a harmonious interplay of natural elements. The region’s vineyards are dotted across undulating morainic hills, which were formed by the retreat of ancient glaciers. These hills offer excellent sun exposure and ventilation to the vineyards, promoting grape ripening and preventing excessive humidity. Additionally, the soils are predominantly composed of glacial deposits and clay, imparting distinct mineral qualities to the grapes.

🍇 Grape Varieties:
Franciacorta wines are crafted primarily from three key grape varieties:

Chardonnay
Pinot Noir
Pinot Blanc

🍷 Wine Styles:
The traditional method of sparkling wine production (Méthode Champenoise) is at the heart of Franciacorta’s winemaking. After the initial fermentation, the base wine undergoes a second fermentation in the bottle, creating those bubbles🍾

Txakoli, also spelled Txakolina, is a unique white wine primarily produced in the Basque Country, which straddles the northern regions of Spain and France. Its origins can be traced back several centuries, with records indicating wine production in this region as early as the 16th century.🇪🇸🇪🇸

One of the key aspects that set Txakoli apart from other wines is its distinct pouring style. Traditionally, it is poured from a specific height, known as “txotx.” The term “txotx” refers to a small wooden barrel tap used to serve the wine directly from large wooden barrels. During the early days, people would gather in the cider houses and follow this unique pouring ritual.

There are 2 reasons behind this high-pouring ritual:

1. Aeration and Flavor Enhancement: By pouring Txakoli from a height, it undergoes aeration, allowing the wine to interact with the oxygen as it pours into the glass. This process enhances the wine’s aromatic qualities and brings out its fresh and fruity notes. The wine acquires a lively, effervescent character, which is highly valued in the Basque culture.

2. Gastronomic Celebration: The high-pouring ritual is also a social event, bringing people together to celebrate gastronomy, camaraderie, and the region’s rich culinary heritage. It’s a special occasion where friends and families come to taste the latest vintage of Txakoli directly from the barrel. This communal experience is an integral part of Basque cultural identity.🥂

So, when you have the chance to sip a glass of Txakoli, raise it high and toast to the time-honored customs that make this wine so special! 🍷🥂

Let’s elevate the way we enjoy sparkling wine by venturing beyond the traditional flutes and embracing the wonders of white wine or universal glasses (a tulip works too)! 🍾

The wider opening of these glasses paves the way for enhanced aromas. Small flutes make it more difficult to get your nose in there, but a white wine or universal glass offers plenty of room.👃🏼

And let’s not forget about taste! The generous bowl size allows the wine to breathe, promoting aeration and enhancing the flavors.

I love the idea of a flute or coupe for certain celebrations (they are fun and pretty), but when it comes to high quality sparklings, it’s a white wine or universal glass for me!

1. Organic wines are made from grapes grown without the use of synthetic pesticides, herbicides, or genetically modified organisms (GMOs). They follow organic farming principles, and the winemaking process avoids synthetic additives and excessive sulfite use.

2. Biodynamic wines take organic farming a step further, following the principles of biodynamic agriculture, which considers the vineyard as a holistic ecosystem. It involves using natural preparations and lunar planting cycles. Biodynamic farming also emphasizes the use of compost and cover crops.

3. Although not technically defined, natural wines are made with minimal intervention. They use organic or biodynamic grapes, but the winemaking process allows for spontaneous fermentation with native yeasts and avoids adding or removing any unnecessary substances. Natural winemakers aim for a more hands-off approach.

SAVE THIS POST - I GET ASKED THIS QUESTION AT EVERY TASTING!

Decanting wine can enhance the drinking experience in two key instances…

Firstly, with young, (especially) full-bodied/high tannin red wines, decanting allows oxygen to interact with compounds in the wine, softening tannins and releasing aromas. This process can help unlock the wine’s potential. 

Secondly, older red wines, particularly those with sediment, benefit from decanting to separate the sediment from the liquid, ensuring a clear pour and preventing unwanted grittiness in your glass.🍷 

Pro tip: champagne connoisseurs like to decant young vintage champagne to allow the aromas to open and effervescence to relax.🥂

MY REAL RAW REVIEW OF CARBONE🍝

Nestled in Greenwich Village and a sanctuary to the world’s A-listers, Carbone is the epitome of exclusivity. In order to lock in a reservation, I had to set Resy alerts for every night in August.📲 

The Amex Patio was actually really well done. It felt like part of the restaurant, but unfortunately you do miss out on the overall vibe and energy of the indoor space. It was fun being able to watch who was going inside though! You’ll definitely catch a celebrity or athlete👀

The wine list was thoughtful and EXTENSIVE showing new and old vintages of coveted wines like Ornellaia and Sassicaia.🍷 Overall it was pricey. We paid $35 for a glass of Michel Gonet Zero Dosage and $195 for a bottle of Girolamo Russo Etna Rosso “San Lorenzo.” You could, however, find some gems under $100 like Volpaia Chianti Classico.

The food was delicious! The spicy rigs had a strong red pepper vibe that I was pleasantly surprised to find, and the veal parm was incredibly flavorful (for $80 it better be) and good for 2 people. It could’ve been pounded out a little thinner, but I loved that it came with the bone. The meatballs were really good and that says a lot coming from me. I think they uncase Italian sausage and add it to the meat mixture. Mine are still better😉

Overall, we liked it! Something we’d try and do once/year because of the price, but we left stuffed and happy. PRO TIP: you can get some incredible rigs in vodka sauce at Peasant!

It’s not the sulfites!🍇

Contrary to popular belief, dried fruits and other foods like french fries, jam, and soda contain higher levels of sulfites than wine, challenging the assumption that sulfites are responsible for those wine-induced headaches.🍷 Instead, it’s often dehydration that’s to blame, as alcohol’s diuretic effect can lead to fluid loss - DRINK MORE WATER!💧

While some individuals may experience headaches from wine due to tannin sensitivity, this is a distinct phenomenon. So next time you enjoy a glass, hydrate wisely, and consider other factors before pointing the finger at sulfites.🫵🏼

Missing our home in Porto🇵🇹

For those who wanted the whole story, Michael and I have always dreamed of owning a place in Europe (we are there so much throughout the year). Due to having close local friends, connections, and resources in Portugal, we thought Porto would be the perfect place to make the dream a reality.

We started looking on @idealistapt in October 2022 and after many failed offers and deals that fell through, we finally found our perfect little “pied-à-terre” in the Cedofeita district (art district) in March 2023 with the help of our realtor, @dvasconcelos73. After some paperwork & bureaucracy, we finally signed June 27th!

I’ve gotten so many questions about buying in Portugal. Here are some quick tips:

1. The Idealista app is a good start if you’re looking for a place in Portugal, Spain, or Italy. It’s like Zillow here in the US
2. It’s super helpful to know a few locals who can give recommendations for realtors - especially ones that have done foreign deals! Thanks, @rafaeldelima91 
3. You’ll need a foreign bank loan and a tax ID number to pay those taxes.💸 In a perfect world, your realtor “has a guy” that can assist with the bank procedures. 
4. Be prepared to put down 20% as a foreigner! 
5. Make sure you go there as many times as possible to check the neighborhoods/streets. Just because you like where it is on the map, doesn’t mean you’ll like the location in person. 

We plan to visit as much as possible (and of course partially retire there), but while we’re not there, it’s available for you to rent! The Airbnb link is in my bio. Lmk if you have any questions about the apartment or process❤️

Incredible day at @feudo_disisa ❤️🇮🇹🍷

Nestled in the heart of the Monreale DOC, Feudo Disisa is a family owned single estate producing incredible wine and olive oil. Once donated to the Archbishop of Monreale by King William II, the Di Lorenzo family has been proprietors for almost 200 years!

We were so lucky to be hosted by the family for a traditional “family lunch” at the estate. The range of wines is extremely impressive, my favorite being “Lu Banco” Catarratto 2021 with expressive notes of ripe meyer lemon, passion fruit, guava, grilled pineapple, saline, smoke, wet stone, with a salty finish😋

For reds, I have to go with the 100% Perricone packed with black cherry, rustic forest berries, violet, rose, smoke, vanilla, dried thyme, and pronounced chewy tannins that will soften over time. 

What a beautiful adventure so far!

✨Ancestral Vibrations✨ In Sicily🇮🇹

My time in Sicily has been so abundant. My cup is overflowing after meeting the generous and hospitable people behind the wine, tasting the unique terroir, and walking on the same soils my great grandparents once lived on (although don’t tell anyone there they were from Gela🤣). 

I find as Americans we can sometimes struggle to connect with our heritage & ancestry because so much was lost, forgotten, or changed when our distant relatives were trying to find a “better place” for their families (if that was the case for you, of course - I understand the privilege in saying this). 

How affirming it is to be here - surrounded by people who look <exactly> like me, enjoying every second of the food, wine, and culture on this island. It’s Italy, but really it’s SICILIA and the people here won’t hesitate to say they’re Sicilian first!🤌🏼

I can’t wait to share more about the wineries, but in the meantime, if you haven’t visited the places where your relatives were from, I can’t recommend it enough. You’ll never regret it.

Excited to share our visit to @faziowines located in the Erice DOC🇮🇹🍷

Vincenzo and Girolamo Fazio transformed their family property into a modern winery and played a key role in establishing the DOC Erice in 2004, emphasizing the connection between production and the unique local terrain.⛰️ We were hosted by Girolamo and his wife Lilly who plays an instrumental role in business development and is the face of the brand.❤️

Their vineyards, covering 100 hectares, are situated at altitudes ranging from 300 to 500 meters above sea level. They cultivate indigenous grape varieties like Inzolia, Grillo, Catarratto, Perricone, Nero d’Avola, and Nerello Mascalese, alongside some international ones such as Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Petit Verdot, and Müller Thurgau. 

They practice organic farming and sustainable viticulture, employing environmentally friendly methods like using biodiesel tractors, and photovoltaic panels for energy needs. Grapes are hand-picked early in the morning to preserve freshness, and their wines are vegan-friendly. In 2017, they even began an experimental vineyard to work with forgotten local grape varieties in collaboration with universities. That was really cool to see!

Did I mention the cannoli were as big as my hands?! The lobster soup was one of my favorite meals of the trip😍🦞

Super huge thanks to my real life, non-wine friends for the inspo.❤️

Primitivo from Puglia (also known in California as Zinfandel) is great for those Apothic red drinkers. It’s usually affordable, and gives ripe, juicy, jammy notes of plum, blackberry, and warm baking spice. These wines are bold, full-bodied, and so ripe they almost finish sweet (and some do have a little residual sugar)! Primitivo labeled “dolce naturale,” are made with grapes that were allowed to raisin on the vine. This causes the sugars to concentrate within the berry making the wine sweet (in a natural way)!

SAVE THIS POST for the simple pairing that stopped me in my tracks!😚🤌🏼

Homemade olive tapenade on olive ciabatta toast with @ferraton_rhone_wines St. Joseph ‘La Source’ was simply heaven!🍷 Ferraton Père et Fils is located in the Rhône Valley producing biodynamic wines throughout the region with respect to terroir. They offer a wide range of cuvées in all price points🙌🏼

This wine is 💯 Syrah which always screams olives to me (IYKYK)!🫒 Here is the simple recipe:

1. Drizzle olive oil on the ciabatta and toast for 10 minutes at 350 degrees
2. In a food processor combine 1 cup of pitted black Kalamata olives & stuffed green olives, 1 clove of crushed garlic, 1 tbsp chopped fresh parsley, and a glug of olive oil
3. Mix until desired texture 
4. Spread on toast and garnish with fresh parsley 

So good & easy and PERFECT for hosting!🍷 Try it out and let me know what you think! OH! And by the way, La Source blanc is available on Wine Access! #Ferraton AD @serawineimports

SAVE THIS POST FOR ONE OF MY FAVORITE SICILIAN PRODUCERS!🍷🇮🇹

@carusoeminini is the result of a unique partnership between two families, the Carusos and Mininis, whose paths converged in 2004 when Stefano Caruso, a third-generation winemaker, crossed with Mario Minini, a marketing expert. Together, they laid the foundations for a modern winery in Marsala, the western tip of Sicily.🇮🇹

The tradition meets innovation as Stefano is joined by his two daughters, Giovanna and Rosanna along with Giovanna’s husband Andrea, who breathe fresh vitality into the winery’s daily operations. 

The heart of Caruso & Minini lies in an old “Baglio” built in 1904, situated in the traditional Marsala wine-cellar area. Their mission is clear: infuse every bottle with the values of tradition while creating a modern expression of Sicilian wines, always focusing on quality and attention to detail. “Let’s make our land travel.”🌱

Their vineyards, Giumarella and Cutaja, span 120 hectares in the inland of Trapani province. These meticulously planned vineyards, ranging from the highest hills to the valley bottoms, house a variety of grapevines from local to international varieties. Each vine is carefully placed to make the most of the unique combination of exposure, soil, and climate.☀️

Thank you thank you for a memorable experience visiting the famous salt pans of Trapani (@salineettoreeinfersa), a great dinner at @mammacaura, and a world-class lunch & tasting at the Baglio! 

You can find these wines on @wine_com!🛒🛍️

Starting Tuesday, I’ll welcome you to Navarra, located in the north of Spain, renowned for its exceptional rosés and a diverse range of white and red wines.🇪🇸 This region’s unique charm is accentuated by its high-latitude vineyards and various microclimates.

A must see when visiting the Navarra wine region! Bardenas Reales is a unique semi-desert region located in the northeast of Spain. This natural wonder features an otherworldly landscape characterized by dramatic sandstone formations, deep canyons, and eroded plateaus. 

Bardenas Reales is renowned for its stunning geological features, including the iconic "Castildetierra" rock formation. It was declared a Natural Park and Biosphere Reserve, making it an important conservation area.

Visitors can explore Bardenas Reales on foot, by bike, or on guided tours, and it's an excellent place to learn about the forces of nature that have shaped this extraordinary landscape over time.🇪🇸

THIS IS NOT A TRICK…IT’S A TREAT👏🏼

In 2007, brothers Xabi, Iñaki, and Mikel Sanz established Viña Zorzal, building upon their family’s winemaking heritage in Correla, Navarra.🇪🇸 Their family had successfully operated Bodegas Correlana for generations, making it an industry benchmark. However, the younger generation diverged from the commercial focus of their father and grandfather, opting for a holistic approach to agriculture.🌱 They concentrated on crafting artisanal wines, with an emphasis on single parcels, single vineyards, and the distinct terroir of Fitero, a subzone of D.O. Navarra.

Unlike the usual flat vineyards in Navarra, their grapevines grow in rocky and stony soils with a mix of clay and limestone. Fun fact: these clay-based soils are like a patchwork quilt, which makes them extra good at resisting erosion.

They’ve got this incredible vineyard of 40 hectares, with 25 of those filled with the classic Garnacha grapes. And get this, some of those wild bush vines are centuries old! Plus, they’re all about organic farming.

But the adventure doesn’t stop in the vineyards. When it’s winemaking time, they let nature do its thing. The wines ferment spontaneously, avoiding filtration and clarification, with only a moderate amount of sulfur used. This meticulous approach preserves the authenticity of the wine.🍷

Look out for this wine on my next “FROM GRAPE TO CHIC” episode🎥 as these wines are BEYOND AFFORDABLE.

An incredible visit with @richiarambarri to taste  @lenaturelwines in the Yerri Valley of the Navarra D.O.🇪🇸🍷

My favorite wine of the trip: Le Natural Lakar🔥🤯

This vineyard in Lakar, Yerri Valley, is 0.8ha in size, planted in 1920 with organic practices. It’s situated at an altitude of 440 meters on calcareous clay soil. The estate features a steep slope where olive, fig, and other fruit trees coexist, promoting polyculture.🌳 The grapes are manually harvested and undergo a short, minimally intervened winemaking process including fermentation in a small concrete tank.

This wine embodies what I truly feel is the trajectory of Navarra: old-vine Garnacha with mouthwatering freshness, vinified with the idea of elegance in mind. The kind of elegance you find in the Côte de Nuits. For real. I’m serious. 

If you want to get excited about this region…I suggest starting here.

This estate symbolizes the essence of Barton & Guestier and their dedication to the world of fine French wines.

Since 1808, the Henriot family has dedicated themselves to crafting the ultimate expression of terroirs from six crus in the Côte des Blancs and Montagne de Reims.🍾

In 2008 the Champagne region experienced an extraordinary year, mirroring the spirit of their founder Apolline Henriot. The weather conditions of the vintage culminated a harvest that embodied Apolline’s vision (which only happens a few times per decade)! It just so happened that in 2008, on the 200th anniversary, the stars aligned perfectly.⭐️

Now, after more than 13 years resting in the cellars, Hemera 2008 emerges as a masterpiece. This exceptional blend, overseen by Cellar Master Alice Tétienne, pays tribute to centuries of prestige winemaking and their commitment to protecting this remarkable region. #ChanpagneHenriot | A D

Straight from the champagne maestro, Olivier Krug’s mouth to your ears!🍾

Traditionally, bubbles are poured into flute glasses as the narrow shape of the glass allows the bubbles to travel further, therefore making them last longer.

It’s great…in theory. However, this narrow passageway restricts the wine’s contact with oxygen, which hinders those aroma compounds from reaching their full potential. You miss a lot of what’s going on in the glass! 

I prefer a universal glass or wide tulip. Although there may not be the same bubble longevity in the universal, you’re getting SO much more aromatically…the whole opera. 

Coupes are fun and bring the vibes; however, the bubbles have absolutely nowhere to go, and the champagne will fall flat in your glass quickly! 

At the end of the day, do you! I’m just letting you in on a little insider tip!🍾

So what is a winter white anyway?❄️

Although this term isn’t exactly “official,” a winter white to me is a white wine with a full body and acidity levels on the medium to lower end. They “hug” your palate the same way a cozy red would. These would be a great winter option for those who believe they may have a tannin sensitivity. 

Here is a list of some of my favorite winter whites:

🍷Rhône Valley whites like Hermitage, Condrieu & Châteauneuf-du-Pape 
🍷Rioja Blanco
🍷Provençal whites (Cassis, Bellet)
🍷Oaked Chardonnay (Napa)
🍷Douro Branco
🍷Semillon (Bordeaux)
🍷Gewürztraminer

I’ve seen these things one too many times, so here’s the 411!

🍷Not tip! Ok so this changes depending on where you are in the world, but I can assure you that if you’re visiting a winery in the US, you need to tip the person pouring and teaching you about the wine. Service is service👏🏼

🍷Not spit. If you want to get hammered do it at home or at a bar - a winery is just not the place. Of course you should always have fun and enjoy your time, but getting obliterated and being disruptive when other people are tasting is pretty obnoxious. Trust me, you’re not offending anyone by spitting out the wine. We all do it!

🍷This last one is a tough tie between showing up right before closing and being vocal to the staff about a wine you don’t like. It’s OK not to like a wine, but we don’t need to make a nasty face and say, “ew I don’t like this at all.” Just spit the wine, dump the glass, and move on.😊

Which one resonates with you? Any others to add?👇🏼

🍷Porto is a beautiful “boutique” city where everything is easily accessible by foot

🍷There is work/life balance

There are several different business models in Champagne, but the most common 2 you’ll come across are Négociant (NM) and Grower (RM). 

“Negociant manipulant” refers to a Champagne House who buys grapes or wine to create their Champagne. They sometimes buy grapes from up to 100+ growers.🧑🏼‍🌾 These wines are made in large quantities and are the ones most commonly found on the shelves. There are MANY I love, but some are overpriced (IMO) due to fantastic marketing (I don’t need to name the wine right? We know).💛 On the upside, due to the quantities of wine made, quality-focused producers have so many blending options available and the space to really age wine for the blends. When I go for a NM wine, I love going for the more special cuvées - but again, it can get expensive. 

On the other hand, “recoltant manipulant” designates a producer who grows their own grapes and uses them to make Champagne.🍇 They have control over the entire winemaking process, from vineyard to bottle. Because of the small production, many don’t have the same marketing budget/resources as the big Houses so you can find incredible wines for less $. I will say, grower champagne has definitely caught on and the prices of the more popular producers have gone up. But again, you can still find some incredible wines with that amazing QPR (measure of bottle’s quality relative to its price):

🍷Henriet-Bazin
🍷André-Jacquart
🍷André Heucq
🍷Fleury
🍷A. Margaine
🍷Pierre Gimonnet & Fils

Splurge-worthy Growers:

🍷Pierre Paillard
🍷R. Pouillon
🍷Bérèche 
🍷Jacquesson
🍷Eric Rodez
🍷Chartogne-Taillet
🍷Georges Laval
